- In the departments I’ve seen, teams do not make any effort into preparing arrival of new employees, criticize them and treat them poorly because they are afraid to lose their jobs and don’t hide it.
- Please MEET the people you will work with if you want to enter the company to make sure they are serious and reliable people. INSIST on that point otherwise don’t take any risks. You will join a team with old employees and you will be on your own.
- All paper and legal requirements documents are neglected by HR. 
- Managers in most of departments are old employees, lost, not enough skills...
- I’ve discussed with a manager who’s having sex with interns. After sleeping with them, The Manager do not extend their contract. They were played, manipulated, gave their body and have to leave. It was the 6x intern the manager was doing it with. Reason The Manager gave is that the personal life is boring @ home so The manager is enjoying time + frustration feeling at PMI
- Men turn around young women easily, I’ve seen an intern where the manager was watching her body and never her face when the intern was talking.. 
- Masculine colleagues turn around the intern and are like, happy watch the « thing ». Even if they see that the intern is not comfortable, they have very inappropriate attitude with most of them.
- They are not open to transforming the company because there are basically only old employees, specially HR. How can you transform with old HR ? They fear for their position as well. 
- No clear information and guidance in every process, very messy
- They don’t take ownership in their responsibilities or recognizing true lack of professionalism. 
- I’ve came across the CEO once and he was hiding to not say hi to people coming across him. He was smocking outside, watching the floor and his phone. If I see someone like that as a CEO, I’ll leave because it explains the vibe of the company. 

And the list can go on into my experience to describe how problematic this company is. 

Seriously if you want to enter this company, make your research, check everything in details, don’t think you’re being picky if they complain, and ask everything that goes in your mind. They are hiding so many informations, teams in some departments lies a lot to HR as well so you will only see their true colors when you are stuck with them. So do your homework in details!!

Overall if you want to have a good resume and experience, just go for a short period of time and then go to a more interesting company because this one is falling in pieces. I Think it's like Nokia with the digital era, PMI did not take their chance in modern times.

review_title: Diverse, Good Ethics, Good Pay- but political to the core.
pros: It's amazing how diverse the company is (maybe not in some Sales teams, but in general) and maybe because the product itself is so controversial, the emphasis on ethics is strong. I also appreciate how the company makes alot of training opportunities - however, I noticed towards my later days that the training opportunity is usually skewed towards high performers. (Since the slot is limited..). There are some amazing senior management who lead by example (though not all). Vision is great, stable overall. Perhaps not a company you'd like to start your career with but maybe a good place to join as a mid-senior. The culture is STRONG. It might fit you, it might not. Some insanely smart people and some very plain people in the same office. It's peculiar. But the long-runners do seem to share a certain character - driven, not too serious about themselves, eloquent, extroverts (atleast, in commercial teams), doesnt mind a bit of politics here and there. Pay was great, at least in my experience.
cons:
Politics. Gossip. Mild to Medium Cut-Throat. But its so obvious so you can steer away from it. :) The cons are not that different from any other company. There will be politicians, free-riders, some incompetent managers and loads of gossip - but PMI is just another big FMCG company with such. Some people stay in this company for decades, which says alot. But sometimes the politics will/could put you off. Just saying, I did see a sub-par sales manager cry at the directors office because she did not get a promotion.
Advice to Management
Please consider bringing back the peer reviews in part of performance reviews! I remember having them at one-point but somewhat disappeared. Though I left the company, I remember that I received the best constructive criticism from them. + ALOT of local P&C people are bullied by senior management (ignoring meeting calls, calling them out for the most random things), which is apparent even to a non-P&C person like me. They bring in alot of good people and help them adjust. It was insanely uncomfortable to watch.

The company is doing well despite the pandemic but it is still relentlessly finding all ways and means to be more "cost efficient". I understand that all companies are focused on the bottom line but at a time when people are losing their jobs and companies are downsizing due to the impact of Covid, shouldn't PMI, who is still doing well, be more humane when they make their business decisions? Why is the company restructuring and planning to let people go at a time when people cannot afford to lose their jobs? Isn't there a better time to do so? Is it really so business critical? It's disappointing when management claims to care for it's people but behind their backs, they are making decisions that show that all they care about is making even more money.

review_title: It used to be much better to work here
pros: The company is very stable and structured. Benefits are great and in most roles provides a good work-life balance. It's great to develop and learn, as they provide lots of training opportunities and the environment is usually challenging.
cons:
The company is going through a big internal transformation (due to their new product/business model) and unfortunately the communication and the change management are super poor. The company closed 2019 with incredibly good earnings, however they keep pushing for global cuts, restructuring everything, launching new global programs, then closing them and changing them, then switching the reporting lines over and over again, cutting benefits (including training and international assignments) and many many other things, all for the sake of "helping the transformation efforts". This situation created such an uncertain environment that every week I hear of someone moving to another company and at least every month some senior manager being "invited to leave". How do you keep working and focusing on your current role and development when there's zero career path and you are always thinking that you might be the next one on the cut? I'm personally looking for external opportunities...
Advice to Management
If all the constant changes are really needed, you should put your main focus on Change Management, making your best efforts to keep your talents and make them feel safe. I am one of many cases where PMI invested lots of money to train and develop, and it would be such a pity to let people like me go and use those skills somewhere else.

review_title: Great teamwork, good employee engagement & result orientation!
pros: Overall, the working environment here is very healthy and positive. Team members work well with each other, within & among departments. Everyone is open-minded and high willingness to accept innovative ideas. Every team member is respecting each other and can easily find supports when necessary. Philip Morris Malaysia supports employee growth and development by providing constructive feedback and suggestions along the journey. Company also offered benefits and flexibility that make it easy to find balance. The employees are aligned with the Company's direction where most of the time we have no trouble staying busying and thriving in our work environments and hence our workday goes by quickly. I carry the pride as part of the PM families.
cons:
I have yet to observe any negative scenarios in the organisation. Perhaps a little bit of hyper-competition?
Advice to Management
Competition amongst the employees is a part of every work space; where a dynamic is created in which employees compete against each other for recognition, remunerations, bonuses, and promotions. The tradition of competitiveness originated from the desire to motivate employees and make them put in more efforts in achieving results. It helped increase both physiological and psychological activation, preparing the body and mind to push boundaries and achieve higher performance. Always engage with the employees and understand the career path in order to drive them for bigger achievements. Avoid employees being too aggressive and workaholic.

review_title: Great place with some unique challenges
pros:
1. True multinational setup, we have many expats in India, most of them bring a lot of International experience, perspective and a no-nonsense approach,, equally local employees do get an opportunity to go outside India on short term(12-18 months) and long term assignments(~36 months)

2. Good pay master, decent benefits

3. Open culture, good global initiatives

4. High visibility and wider scope of roles(smaller org with ~100 people)

5. Good location in Delhi (Aerocity)

6. Excellent and liberal T&E policies, all employees get similar treatment(policies) regardless of designation or grades. >5 hour air travel and you get a business class ticket :)

7. Focus on job rotation and mobility, if you adapt to the culture and are willing to take those extra steps, a very fruitful and monetarily rewarding career awaits you
cons:
1. The type of business that the company operates in (tobacco), and being in wholesale business, puts a lot of restrictions on quality of work. While profiles are wider but most of them are likely to lack depth. For example, your definition of marketing manager in FMCG industry and profile that someone should expect in IPM will be quite different(diluted)

2. Being an MNC, driven mostly by global KPIs and initiatives.. they at times may not make the most business sense from the local affiliate point of view. Someone not coming from an MNC background may find difficult to adapt

3. Some functions may be facing a leadership crisis, while a lot of processes, training, coaching etc goes in, not all SMTs are of same mold.

4. Global mobility is a requirement, if you are unwilling to move out of India, this may become a hindrance once you move up the ladder. Given the smaller team size, moving out of India becomes a necessity after a point, else your career growth will suffer.
Advice to Management
HR needs to play a more active role in career cycle management of employees.

pros: Salary. International environment. Great facilities.
cons:
Hollow and cold, with nothing below the surface. No sense of team. Individualism. Zero core values. Management makes no effort to fully integrate their employees. Many employees using alternative tobacco products in offices and meetings with complete disregard for the feelings of others. High turnover due to many short-term assignments - thus difficult to build long term and meaningful relationships at work. The yearly review is badly organized and management doesn't care about their subordinate's career progress.
Advice to Management
Walk the talk and stop the witch hunt mentality when you give the option of an anonymous review and get answers that are difficult to digest. Clean out your upper ranks with old and stale tobacco industry opinions. Let new-hires, whom you recruit to do a specific job actually do what they are hired for, instead of wasting vast sums of money on big San-Fran grab-it-all agencies who keep repeating the same mantra for over one year. If you change your directors and get real leaders from outside the tobacco industry, then you will find that they know how to drive talent and get the best results from them - your existing upper management hasn't got a clue how to really integrate and use people and culture approaches, because they are all stuck in the business from 20-30 years ago... it's really time for change and REAL TRANSFORMATION!

review_title: Terrible company. Worklife balance does not exist (only words)
pros:
Good salaries
Available kid's day care (at a cost).
cons:
The year review is not fair. The extremely competitive environment favours single people, expacts with no attachments, and workaholics. And the company employs a lot of people who can focus essentially on work 24/7.
Managing work expectations whilst managing a familly life is impossible.
If you have familly and both parents work there, something will give in.

Visibility is the big word going around. It doesn't matter if you do something or even if you do it well, as long as you present it, and give a good impression, you can make a career.
Extra time is taboo. Everyone works way above 40h/week, but no one counts this extra time. When managers are faced with requests for extra time, they avoid the subject.
The salary is good... However if you count the extra time that you put in (which you cannot claim), then philip morris is paying you less than other companies.
Advice to Management
Change the MAP (year end job review). Having a quota for success/failure only creates problem. I worked over 10 years there, I never heard anyone happy about the process. 
When everyone worked really hard, giving a bad review is not normal. Giving it in order to respect a quota is even worse. 
Simply because someone did not work as long as his colleagues that can work 14 hours per day.
Unfortunately a lot of managers keep pushing for more and more. 
The more people give, the more PMI wants.

pros:
Great compensation and benefits
Great carreer opportunities
Incomparable learning experiences
Very ethical. This is something that might sound funny for a tobacco company, but PMI is extremely correct and respectfull with law, competitiveness polices and comitted to being transparent and correct with anything they do.
cons:
Veeeeery stressfull.
Straight taditional style: vertical hierarchy, long hours job, fixed schedule, clock in at the office (even if it doesn't make any sense). If you enjoy startup style, PMI is definetely not for you. There is a global initiative to change this "manners", but it is happening very slowly - sometimes it feels like it is not happening at all. It is frustrating for a millenial, because it seems like you're working on the 1980's. 

Last but not least, there is a very strong need of being supported by the right people. There are several cases of people on important/powerfull positions who are not qualified nor prepared to be there. Most of the leaders are like that, and lack of people and managing skills. 

I believe PMI is working hard to change the organizational culture and investing a lot on it. It is also a part of the iQOS "mindset", it's innovative. But I highly doubt that PMI will get there soon, or easily. Some people will just not fit, and most of them are considered important assets - and I am afraid they will not leave.
Advice to Management
Retire! You guys rocked a few years ago, but things are not like they were and it is clear that most of you are not ready to change. And I am pretty sure you guys are tired anyway... so go. Be happy!
